IRM content was revised to reﬂect current NRP examination processes and procedures.
- Added a paragraph to mandate NRP training for group
Throughout this IRM section, editorial changes were made to add clarity, correct misspellings and grammar, and to update or add citations and references.

) Purpose. This IRM section provides guidance for conducting examinations NRP key case tax returns. The types of returns applicable to these cases and include examinations of: • Form
, Individual Income Tax - IRM
) Audience. This information applies to IRS employees who are involved in examination process of NRP selected returns: • Territory managers • Group managers • Examiners • Reviewers • NRP staff (
) Director, Knowledge Development and Application under Research, Applied Analytics and Statistics (RAAS) is the policy owner. (
) NRP is the program office responsible for the oversight of the NRP studies. (
) For information about the National Research Program, visit the NRP at: https://nrp.web.irs.gov. (

) The IRS needs reliable compliance measures to determine which key areas noncompliance to address and which treatments to apply to maximize the of its limited resources. Data provided by NRP examinations gives us the mation to meet these needs. (

) NRP applies speciﬁc guidelines to existing examination techniques and processes to capture necessary compliance data. Using enhanced internal formation and established processes, NRP minimizes the burden to both the taxpayer and examination personnel. (
) NRP results are available for the IRS to effectively manage its compliance programs and design pre-ﬁling activities that help taxpayers comply with the tax law. (
) NRP is critical to the organizational transformation of the IRS. NRP is one of several efforts the IRS is using to enhance its compliance-oriented (
) By law, the Service has the authority to conduct examinations under Title Internal Revenue Code, Subtitle F – Procedure and Administration, Chapter
, Discovery of Liability and Enforcement of Title, Subchapter A, and Inspection, which includes, but is not limited to, the following IRC • IRC
, Examination of books and witnesses • IRC
, Time and place of examination Note: Additional information related to conducting examinations is contained in CFR
, Statement of Procedural Regulations. (
) Under the Reform and Restructuring Act of
(RRA ’
), Congress mandated the IRS to deliver service to taxpayers at a new and much higher level of performance in the most cost-effective and least burdensome (

Audience. This information applies to IRS employees who are involved in the examination process of NRP selected returns:
NRP is critical to the organizational transformation of the IRS. NRP is one of several efforts the IRS is using to enhance its compliance-oriented

Under the Reform and Restructuring Act of 1998 (RRA ’98), Congress mandated the IRS to deliver service to taxpayers at a new and much higher level of performance in the most cost-effective and least burdensome manner
4.22 National Research Program
possible. Data from NRP examinations enable the IRS to operate as a efficient and effective tax administration organization. (
) Director, Research, Applied Analytics and Statistics (RAAS) oversees the Program. (
) Director, Data Management Division (DMD) oversees the Compliance Data Warehouse (CDW). (
) Chief, National Research Program manages and monitors NRP operations provides guidance. This is the office with primary responsibility for ing the NRP program. (

) For all NRP studies, the NRP Office manages and monitors NRP and provides guidance and assistance to all participating Business Divisions (Small Business and Self Employed (SB/SE), Large Business and International (LB&I) and Tax Exempt and Government Entities (TE/GE)) as needed. (
) Examination Directors have responsibility for NRP examinations within their areas. (
) Territory Managers have responsibility for NRP examinations within their ries. (

) The Planning and Special Programs (PSP) Territory Manager (TM) will nate the receipt, control, and assignment of NRP returns. The PSP TM will monitor and report on the status of the NRP inventory, approve transfer of cases and have second line authority for approval/disapproval of exclusion requests. (

) Group Managers and Case Managers are responsible for NRP cases their groups, including timely assignment of NRP cases, and providing guidance to examiners on the scope and requirements of these They are also responsible for maintaining a workﬂow throughout the entire amination cycle that ensures timely completion. To ensure the quality of examinations, managers will review cases according to procedures outlined this IRM. (

) Effective management of the NRP study is achieved by training the NRP managers and examiners. This ensures that quality examinations are conducted and the IRS gets good data. a. Only examiners who complete NRP training will work NRP cases. b. Group Managers with NRP cases in their group are also required to complete the applicable Integrated Talent Management (ITM) NRP training course. c. Examiners with NRP cases assigned to them and group managers NRP cases in their group are required to complete the Integrated Management (ITM) NRP training course on an annual basis for as as the NRP cases are active. d. The number of NRP examiners appointed will be sufficient to handle NRP workload. e. Qualiﬁed examiners at appropriate grade levels will be assigned NRP cases. Internal Revenue Manual Cat. No.
N
possible. Data from NRP examinations enable the IRS to operate as a more efficient and effective tax administration organization.
Director, Research, Applied Analytics and Statistics (RAAS) oversees the NRP

Only examiners who complete NRP training will work NRP cases. Group Managers with NRP cases in their group are also required to complete the applicable Integrated Talent Management (ITM) NRP training course. Examiners with NRP cases assigned to them and group managers with NRP cases in their group are required to complete the Integrated Talent Management (ITM) NRP training course on an annual basis for as long as the NRP cases are active. The number of NRP examiners appointed will be sufficient to handle the NRP workload. Qualiﬁed examiners at appropriate grade levels will be assigned NRP cases.

) Acronyms relating to the NRP examination include: a. AIMS - Audit Information Management System b. CDW - Compliance Data Warehouse c. DIF - Discriminant Function d. ERCS - Examination Returns Control System e. EOAD – Examinational Operational Automation Database f. ITM - Integrated Talent Management g. KITA - Killed In Terrorist Action h. LB&I - Large Business and International Division i. NRP - National Research Program j. PSP - Planning and Special Programs k. SAC - Special Agent in Charge l. SB/SE - Small Business and Self Employed Division m. TE/GE - Tax Exempt and Government Entities (

, NRP EITC Component of the Individual Reporting Compliance Study (

) The NRP examination process follows the normal examination process to extent possible. By adhering to normal examination processes and proce- dures, NRP is able to minimize the burden to both the taxpayer and while still capturing the necessary data. Each NRP study consists of the following processes for a single tax year: a. Sample Selection – Each NRP study selects a statistically valid, strati- ﬁed random sample of returns. Data from the sampled returns produce set of data that is representative of the study population from which returns were selected. With appropriate weighting, the results from the sample returns can be used to develop estimates for the study popula- tion. b. Case Building – Refer to IRM
NRP Case Building, for detailed information about the NRP Case Building process. c. Classiﬁcation – Refer to IRM
Classiﬁcation of NRP Returns, for detailed information about the NRP Classiﬁcation process. d. Examination – Except as otherwise speciﬁed in IRM
of NRP Returns, existing examination processes and procedures are to be followed for NRP cases. e. Data Transmission – Refer to IRM
Examination of NRP Returns, for detailed information about the NRP Data Transmission process. (

) To facilitate continued improvements to NRP studies and processes, the staff will communicate with the Area, Territory, or Industry Offices in tion with the NRP Coordinators, to solicit feedback and insights on each These discussions should include any recommended changes for future studies, taxpayer reactions to the program and ways of accomplishing NRP with reduced taxpayer and examiner burden.

To facilitate continued improvements to NRP studies and processes, the staff will communicate with the Area, Territory, or Industry Offices in coordina- tion with the NRP Coordinators, to solicit feedback and insights on each These discussions should include any recommended changes for future studies, taxpayer reactions to the program and ways of accomplishing NRP with reduced taxpayer and examiner burden. NRP electronic case ﬁles contain all case building items in electronic format. Contents of any paper case ﬁles will vary by study. Refer to IRM
, Case Building, for additional details.
National Research Program (
) Upon receipt of NRP case ﬁles, the receiving office will verify that the elec- tronic and any paper case ﬁles are complete and agree with the transmittal list ( Form
). If ﬁles don’t agree with the accompanying mittal, contact the NRP Office at the following e-mail address: ctr.aus.nrp@irs.gov. (
) After veriﬁcation, the receiving office will sign and date (on each page) the original and one copy of the transmittal lists (Form
) within ﬁve (
) NRP cases are processed as part of the normal examination workload otherwise speciﬁed herein. (
) After receipt of cases from the NRP Coordinator, Group Managers and Managers will assign cases to examiners as quickly as possible. (
) NRP examinations will only be conducted by examiners who have the required NRP training. NRP examinations should be completed without sacriﬁcing quality. (

) Examiners with NRP cases assigned to them and group managers with cases in their group are required to complete the Integrated Talent ment (ITM) NRP training course on an annual basis for as long as the cases are active. (

) Examinations of NRP returns are generally held face-to-face. Exceptions this will be made after concurrence by management on a case by case There will be no surveys before or after assignment unless certain criteria are met. (

) Examinations will be conducted consistent with existing examination unless they conﬂict with instructions contained herein. If conﬂicts arise with existing examination guidelines, NRP guidelines take precedent. (
) Where possible, perform ﬁeld examinations at the taxpayer’s place of to permit actual observation of the taxpayer’s business facilities and extent operations. See IRM
) , Where to Conduct Interviews. (
) Prior/Subsequent or Related returns are not required for NRP Key cases. Examiners should follow IRM
, Required Filing Checks, and that all required related returns and prior/subsequent year returns were a. If a prior/subsequent or related return is picked up for examination, Source Code
when establishing the control on AIMS/ERCS. b. If a prior/subsequent or related return is picked up for examination, use the appropriate Project Code and Tracking Code for the study and tax year.

) If indications of fraud are discovered during the examination of an NRP or related return, make a referral in accordance with the procedures in IRM Fraud Handbook. a. Label the referral as an NRP case. Such identiﬁcation is necessary so that the Special Agent in Charge (SAC) can recognize it as being an NRP return. b. If the case is accepted for joint investigation and a reasonably estimate of the results cannot be made during the NRP examination period, the NRP Office will provide additional guidance. (
) If an NRP return crosses Operating Divisions, contact your NRP Coordinator for guidance. (

) When an examiner determines or is notiﬁed that an NRP and/or any related return is being controlled by the Partnership Control System (PCS), the examiner will contact the agent working the related case to ﬁnd out when reliable information can be expected concerning adjustments that affect the NRP examination. Follow-up periodically to ensure that reliable information provided timely. (
) Alert Area Counsel immediately in all instances involving summons enforce- ment regarding an NRP case. Also, inform the NRP Office by memorandum such cases as soon as they arise. (

) Under certain circumstances, NRP returns may be removed from the study. addition to the exclusion criteria in this IRM, there are systemic conditions the procedures for requesting exclusions of NRP cases. (

) If the examiner ﬁnds that an examination cannot be conducted for reasons other than those listed in this IRM, the manager should notify the NRP nator. The NRP Coordinator will contact the NRP program office to the NRP case can be excluded from the study. (
) All problems not speciﬁcally covered in this section will be resolved jointly

National Research Program (

) Importance of NRP Results -The examination outcomes of NRP returns provide the data used to understand the extent and nature of noncompliance of for the relevant population of returns from which the NRP returns are drawn. These data are used in many ways. Primary among these are developing compliance estimates, including the tax gap estimates; developing estimates satisfy the reporting requirements of the Improper Payments Information Act (IPIA) of

as amended; and developing or updating models for scoring returns as to their probability of signiﬁcant tax understatement. The scope depth of the examination of an NRP-selected return should be sufficient to provide reliable information for these purposes. Examiners should be mindful of causing unnecessary burden for the taxpayer. (

) Scope of Examination - Every classiﬁed item must be examined. An inquiry or an inspection of records and documents must be made for all classiﬁed items. If an examiner has a question about the classiﬁed issues, refer to IRM

, Classiﬁcation of NRP Returns, for further instruction. a. Expansion of Audit Scope - If the examination reveals issues in addition to those classiﬁed, the examiner should expand the to include the additional items. Materiality is never a factor for the scope of the NRP key case. b. Related Entity Examinations - If the examiner chooses to pick-up a related return or entity, controls must be established. If the related entity is outside the group control, the examiner will follow the procedures outlined in IRM

, Collateral Referrals. Note: Related return examinations are not NRP sample returns. The ex- aminations of any related entities are not subject to the requirements of an NRP examination. The scope is determined by the examiner. Related returns are not subject to the NRP lines. (

) Depth of Examination - Examiners must use their professional judgment cerning the depth of examination required for any item on the tax return bearing in mind the future uses of the data collected from the examinations. See IRM

, Evaluation of Books and Records. a. The depth of the examination of an NRP examination is the same as a non NRP examination. NRP taxpayers must not be held to a higher standard or more in-depth audit procedures. b. Pursue issues to the depth necessary to reach a supportable Oral testimony may be accepted in appropriate situations. See IRM
, Issue Resolution. (

) Mandatory Probes - At a minimum, conduct some inquiry or inspection of records and documents supporting classiﬁed or mandatory items including, not limited to, income, deductions, taxes and credits. In the examination of all NRP cases, be equally alert to discovering unreported income, as well as allowing taxpayers any additional deductions or credits to which they are entitled. Given the variety of taxpayers and types and sources of income and deductions, it is not practical to give speciﬁc guidelines for the scope and depth of such inquiry. This is a matter of judgment in each case. For income probes refer to IRM
, Examination of Income. (
) Required Workpaper Documentation - Lead sheets and any supporting workpapers are required for each issue, must be prepared electronically, and Internal Revenue Manual Cat. No.
N Any line marked with a is for Official Use

) Required Workpaper Documentation - Lead sheets and any supporting
Required Workpaper Documentation - Lead sheets and any supporting workpapers are required for each issue, must be prepared electronically, and
page 7

included in the applicable electronic case ﬁle. Lead sheets must contain the adjustment amount, audit procedures and conclusion. In addition, certain issues require completion of an NRP-speciﬁc lead sheet that contains data capture features. All supporting workpapers must be properly named so they can be associated with the appropriate issue/lead sheet. RGS users refer to IRM 4.10.15.7.19 for general lead sheet and workpaper information and re- quirements.

Audit procedures and conclusions for each issue audited must be supported by written comments in the workpapers regardless of an adjustment was made. This is necessary to ensure that the data gathered for NRP is accurate and complete. Examiners must describe what inquiry or inspection of records or documents was made to verify reported or possible unreported income, deductions and credits.

formation. a. Information on how to access and complete the Lead Sheets is in the training material and within the Lead Sheets. b. Do not delete any tabs on NRP Lead Sheets. c. NRP Lead Sheets must remain in Excel for proper data capture. d. NRP Lead Sheets can be renamed to include the Issue Reference Number according to revised SBSE electronic case ﬁle guidelines. e. An NRP initial interview supplemental questionnaire is provided to examiners with the initial interview. (
) NRP examiners should gather facts to determine the accuracy of any item classiﬁed for examination. This determination should include all the facts porting both sides of an issue. (

) Documentary evidence is emphasized in the conduct of an NRP Records kept contemporaneously with the occurrence of an event generally reﬂect accurately of that event. Books of original entry should be obtained if they exist. The contemporaneous records, invoices, bank statements, cancelled checks, and any other documents to support the books and should be inspected to a depth adequate to support the accuracy of those books and records. (

) In situations where contemporaneous books and records do not exist or are incomplete, secondary written records (such as, copies of original obtained from third parties) or other reconstructions of records, if credible, be used. (

) Oral testimony by a taxpayer is direct evidence which must be thoroughly sidered. The degree of reliability placed on a taxpayer’s oral testimony must based on the credibility of the taxpayer and the surrounding circumstantial evidence. (
) Oral testimony by other than the taxpayer may also be credible if that has ﬁrst-hand knowledge of the facts and circumstances.

a. Information on how to access and complete the Lead Sheets is in the training material and within the Lead Sheets. b. Do not delete any tabs on NRP Lead Sheets. c. NRP Lead Sheets must remain in Excel for proper data capture. d. NRP Lead Sheets can be renamed to include the Issue Reference Number according to revised SBSE electronic case ﬁle guidelines. e. An NRP initial interview supplemental questionnaire is provided to examiners with the initial interview.
Oral testimony by other than the taxpayer may also be credible if that person has ﬁrst-hand knowledge of the facts and circumstances.
National Research Program (
) The steps to obtain evidence and the evaluation of it should be documented the issue’s workpapers. (

) Due to the future uses of the data collected through the NRP examinations, adjustments must be entered and captured within RGS, IMS or the study Adjustments speciﬁc Data Capture Instrument (DCI) on the key case examination only. (
) Each NRP Study has its own requirements regarding de minimis For more information, refer to the applicable NRP training courses at https:// nrp.web.irs.gov/training. (

) Wrong line adjustments occur when a taxpayer reports an amount on the wrong line of an income tax return. They include: Adjustments a. Decreasing an amount that was reported (solely or as part of a larger amount) on the return and then allowing the amount elsewhere on the return, OR b. Decreasing an amount that was reported (solely or part of a larger amount) on the return and then allowing that amount split among two more line items, AND c. Affects or potentially affects the ﬁnal tax liability. (
) All wrong line adjustments must net to zero. (

) Wrong line adjustments do not include: a. Increasing an amount that was reported (solely or as part of a larger amount) on the return. If the increase relates to an amount that was reported by the taxpayer on the wrong line, make the adjustment to correct line. b. Increasing or decreasing an amount as a result of adjustment(s) made another return (prior, subsequent or related). (
) Each NRP Study has its own guidance regarding wrong line adjustments. more information, refer to the applicable NRP training courses at: https://nrp. web.irs.gov/training. (

) Guidelines for making wrong line adjustments include: a. For each affected return line item, don’t combine wrong line with other adjustments. If necessary, add issues in RGS to capture the wrong-line adjustments separately. Note: It’s acceptable to combine other adjustments (to the same line) one issue. b. Use Reason Codes “
” or “
”, as appropriate, to describe all wrong line adjustments c. The sum of wrong line adjustments made to the NRP key case must equal zero. (
) Cases with ﬂow-through income and expenses to other entities have special considerations. Form
, Form
S, and Form
provide for items income and expense to be distributed as ordinary income or (loss) and as separately distributed items (per Schedule K-

and return attachments). In completing a report for examination changes at the conduit level, the should not reﬂect changes that are in name only and used to determine Internal Revenue Manual Cat. No.

Wrong line adjustments occur when a taxpayer reports an amount on the wrong line of an income tax return. They include:
Returns

page ordinary income or (loss). If changes result in adjustments to the distributed items which could (based on statutory limitations and other requirements at shareholder/partner level) affect tax liability, then the examiner should make those adjustments and use the appropriate Reason Code “
” or “

) Even though wrong line adjustments may not affect the determination of taxable or ordinary income, their true nature can have a deﬁnite effect on the determination of tax liability for the NRP return or the shareholder associated with the NRP return. These changes (such as those to Self-Employment Tax, Minimum Tax, Earned Income Credit, etc.,) should be reﬂected on the report. In addition, changes should be made to misclassiﬁed items on a Form
that could result in changes to the shareholder return due to statutory or other limitations at the recipient’s level. (
) Once a decision has been made to transfer a case to another area and the requirements of IRM
, Transfer of Returns Open for Examination, been met, the following procedures apply: (
) A completed Form

, Transfer of Return, with “NRP study cycle” clearly entered in the “Comments” section should be used to transmit NRP cases and any related data to the transferee Area NRP Coordinator for review and updating of control records. The Area NRP Coordinator should establish local procedures for expediting transfers, both into and out of the Area. (
) Upon receipt of the NRP package, the receiving Area must acknowledge receipt by updating the NRP control system and by signing and Form
, Document Transmittal. a. The transferring Area NRP Coordinator should review Form
cally to see if the “Acknowledgment Copy” of Form
has been received. b. If it has not been received within
days, follow-up action should be taken by contacting the transfer-out clerk within the Area and, if necessary, the receiving Area NRP Coordinator. (
) The NRP Coordinator should also review the “Transfer Pending” report on the NRP control system periodically to see if any cases are being transferred into the Area. If a case is not received within

calendar days of the “Sent” date, the transferee Area NRP Coordinator should contact the transfer-in clerk the Area and if necessary, the transfer-out Area NRP Coordinator to ensure transfer completion. (
) Formal discussions between the transferrer and transferee Areas are strongly recommended, to eliminate questionable transfers.
those adjustments and use the appropriate Reason Code “

calendar days of the “Sent” date, the transferee Area NRP Coordinator should contact the transfer-in clerk within the Area and if necessary, the transfer-out Area NRP Coordinator to ensure transfer completion. Formal discussions between the transferrer and transferee Areas are strongly

NRP will test all transmitted data to ensure it is complete and consistent.
